Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Typical order: RO -> CA -> RI -> PI -> QC -> PO -> GSL -> D -> IC -> RP.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: we assume each activity occurs exactly once per case... So we assume successful flow. Possibly we have a simple sequential process: RO -> CA -> RI -> PI -> QC -> PO -> GSL -> D -> IC -> RP.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Usually, equivalence is used for activities that are in a one-to-one correspondence, like two activities that always appear together. ... I think its safe to leave equivalence empty

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: always_before as: - (CA, RO) - (RI, CA) - (PI, RI) - (QC, PI) - (PO, QC) - (GSL, PO) - (D, GSL) - (IC, D) - (RP, IC)

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: always_after pairs: (RO, CA), (CA, RI), (RI, PI), (PI, QC), (QC, PO), (PO, GSL), (GSL, D), (D, IC), (IC, RP).

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: never_together: Activities that cannot both occur in the same case. Are there any? Possibly none... So Ill set never_together to empty set.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: directly_follows = { (RO, CA), (CA, RI), (RI, PI), (PI, QC), (QC, PO), (PO, GSL), (GSL, D), (D, IC), (IC, RP) }

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: In always_after, I had (PO, SL) but the activity is GSL. So fix: (PO, GSL).

Name: Validation - PE
Text: So the chain enforces the presence of all predecessors... Lets double-check the always_before and always_after
